title: (x) 1960s/70s The Omega Man - Rubens {Mark S}
content:
Hello All,   
   
The following is a screen capture from the movie The Omega Man. It features a font I've seen many times being used in projects of the period (1960s-early 80s). Perhaps it's most notable use was as the typeface used for the Knight Rider television show. I've tried my usual sources. Does anyone know its name and whether it's been digitized?   
   
 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/23568.jpg)
author: James Gareth

comments.content: Rubens Extended (except for the omega character).
Or maybe not. There's another one in the Solotype Catalog called Kildare that looks like a better match.

Thanks Mark! Quick catch. Is this available anywhere commercially? All I found was this:   
   
 [http://home.together.net/~jordy/Pages/rubens1.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/home.together.net/~jordy/Pages/rubens1.html)
It doesn't appear to be available commercially. A bit surprising as it was pretty common in the phototype days.

[This](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.myfonts.com/foundry/solotype/) is an interesting development!   
   
And [here](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/excelsis/) is your font, Excelsis.   
   
 [More on Dan X. Solo](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.myfonts.com/person/solo/dan/x/)

Laurence and some of the MyFontsFolks probably did that same dance ...   
   
I did a doubletake, then smiled and had that Good For Him feeling

[Excelsis](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/solotype/excelsis/) is similar but not quite identical to Rubens. I remember seeing Rubens on one of the Solotype CD's, probably the Victorian one. [Castcraft/Optifont](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.castcraft-software.com/) also sells [a version](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.castcraft-software.com/designer3/designer3.11.html). There is a "freeware" version of dubious origin under the name [Ruben](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.grimghosts.com/down/fonts/fonts.html).   
   
I worked on a new digitization of a condensed Rubens-style typeface, based on typography from Disney's Haunted Mansion attractions. It's called [Ravenscroft](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.grimghosts.com/down/fonts/fonts.html) and is freeware.   
   
 [Treehouse](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.frontiernet.net/~treehous/Typefaces.html) also has a Haunted Mansion inspired font called [Victorian Mansion](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.frontiernet.net/~treehous/Mansion.html).

Linotype's [Macbeth](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/macbeth/macbeth/testdrive.html?s=THE%20OMEGA%20MAN%20-%20CHARLTON%20HESTON&p=36) is of a different weight, but apart   
from a couple of characters it's _very_ close. It could   
do the trick.

It sure is! Holy macaroni it's about time! Good one BJ!   
(does little indian dance around his desk)
(suddenly notices baffled look on colleagues' faces)

I know this is an old thread, but I thought I'd concur with gargoyle that my font, "Mansion,"  
 is the style you are looking for. It's a Haunted Mansion font that was also used in the TV show "Knight Rider."

You can check it out at [http://davidocchino.com/portfolio/typography/mansion.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20150323000442/http:/davidocchino.com/portfolio/typography/mansion.html "http://davidocchino.com/portfolio/typography/mansion.html")

David Occhino  
David Occhino Design
